Presented to Student Council
by Tom McNamara
At Wednesday's Student Council meeting, President Mark
Komisky distributed a draft of a
statement on freedom of expression. He said that the document
was compiled from statements
given to him by Buildings and
Grounds Chairman Jim Finnerty
and Sophomore Class Representative Susan Land.
Council has not yet voted on

although Komisky has asked for
help in preparing another version
for presentation at the next
meeting.

represents "a sort of comprehensive memo" to the Hopkins community on the subject. According
to its introduction, the "statement

is by no means to be a definitive
work on freedom of expression
but rather is to serve as a basis for
further discourse on the issue."

that the "Flathman Report"
issued by the University's Committee on Freedom of Expression
"leans toward the notion of an
absolute freedom, however,
discussion among many members
of the Hopkins community has
pointed toward the need for further investigation."

issues related to fieedom of expression. It defines a "legitimate
act of free expression" as "any
act intended by the agent to communicate to other persons some
proposition, position, attitude,
etc., with significance to a

generality of interest. This includes displays of symbols and
demonstrations."

statement in the memo, "certain
expressions must be limited in
some circumstances by balancing
their value with the requirements
of essential and necessary functioning of the University and
comtemporary social norms.
Definition of these norms must be
interpreted quite liberally to allow
for new ideas but must also include restrictions pertaining to
crude, ludicrous, and generally
unproductive actions."

To the Editor:

It has come to the attention of
the Whackers that the NewsLetter golf writer has been
writing libelous and scandalous
articles. We feel that we must set
the record straight.
First, Nashah Adu is actually
"Hoagie-Boy" Handa, the inconsistent number four player for the
Hopkins Golf squad. He uses this
pen name in order to heap praise
upon himself as "Luigi" Handa.
Second, Jack Savitz shot a 93
instead of Handa's reported 133
in the match against Gettysburg.
Further, Tony Wu is only an
alleged Whacker. (I'm sure he
whacks, but not for the Hopkins
Golf Team. He is a catcher for
the baseball team.) Tony said he
is in good health but Handa insists
that he has "inside" information
about this former whacker.
Third, it was Handa, not
Schiller, who was brought before
the discipline committee. Ashu
"We Are The World" Handa
was disqualified in the match
against Dickinson for illegally
stroking his opponents' ball(s).
We demand a printed apology
and question such journalistic un
professionalism. Handa is an
eyesore in the fine News-Letter
staff.

In the last issue of the NewsLetter, a letter writer referred to
protesters at the CIA demonstration as the dregs 'and scum of
Baltimore. I find this comment
both appalling and extremely sad
and I sincerely hope that I am not
alone.
In calling people, people,
scum, the author seems to have
forgotten those things that he and
the objects of his ridicule have in
common—a capacity to love and
dislike, to experience joy and
pain, to have self-respect, and so
forth. These are the things by virtue of which we are human
beings—by so distancing himself
from and degrading a group of
people, the author has, in a single
sentence, denied them their
humanity.
When most of us consider other
people, we usually think of our
differences, but it is a sad day, I
think, when we so emphasize our
differences, that we forget those
things that we all have in
common.

Jack Savitz
Steve Schiller

On Media: Small Producers are Back
by Robert Zimmerman
The movie industry is not like
it used to be. Unlike those
paradigms of power, like Sam
Goldwyn and David 0. Selznick,
today's movers and shakers are
moving around a lot and are very
shaky. Executives are losing jobs
quickly, and moving from studio
to studio even quicker. And
strategy has .changed: companies
bet on blockbuster movies to rake
in the profits and support the few
"serious" films they make.
While everyone tries to make
E. T. this leads to more
expensive—and more risky—
projects. After the failure of the
mega-expensive
Heaven's
Gate, Universal Studios had to
close.
Smaller, independent studios
are starting to emerge as new
powers in the movie industry.
Never a powerful force befcile,
the Hollywood hierarchy is get-

ting mixed up as studios never
considered "big" are starting to
infiltrate. Disney movies, written
off by Hollywooders as a cartoonfactory or a haven for Dean Jones
and Ken Berry, are back. With
Touchstone Films, Michael
Eisner has put Disney on the map
in three years.
The most startling and telling
rise is that of Cannon Pictures.
The two-man team of GolamGlobus that started, runs, and
basically is Cannon, has made the
company into the biggest independent on the movie scene.
What was only ten years ago a
third-rate independent studio that
produced dozens of low-budget
hack-and-slay horror flicks, is
now signing contracts with
Walter Matthau, Roman Polanski, and Sylvester Stallone.
In the forties, movie studios
owned a lot of their own movie
theatres, so they had places to
show the films and they got the

extra revenue. The studios today
don't do that. But Cannon did
that. Cannon Group owns over 50
movie theatres in Europe, making money for Cannon by showing Cannon films. A good
strategy.
What movie studios also don't
do today is make different kinds
of movies. As I said before,
everyone is trying to make
E.T. In the days of Sam
Goldwyn, studios had their
gangster films, their comedies,
their westerns, their musicals and
their serious films. Cannon alone
has begun to go back to that old
trend of spending less on movies
and expecting less of a return.
However, by targeting at specific
audiences, they are more assured
of the size profit they'll expect.
So, while they still churn out
blood-and-gore flicks, they also
have produced comedies (The
Private Eyes) and low-budget
serious films.

Cannon has started to attract
real stars. Roman Polanski
directed Pirates for them. The
comedy-adventure, which starred
Walter Matthau, was a flop. But
next year expect to see a Cannon
movie directed by Matthau. The
most talked about event in Cannon's history was their signing of
Sylvester Stallone to star in
Over the Top. While they did
indeed pay Sly a hefty $12 million
to play the hero in this armwrestling epic, it's not overpriced considering Marlon Brando got the same amount for his
cameo in Superman. And
whereas Brando's appearance as
Superman's father added very little to the movie (Gene Hackman
stole the whole movie anyway),
Stallone's name made this—
Cannon's first blockbuster
movie—profitable.
Sure, Over the Top wasn't
anything like Cobra or Rambo. But with foreign distribu-

tion, and video and cable rights,
Cannon made nice money on the
deal. So when you wonder who's
going to be producing the films
that'll be winning the awards at
Cannes in five years, it may be
Cannon.
The big Hollywood studios
could learn a lot from those two
middle-aged Israelis. Like that
audiences don't all want to see
another E.T.

Whackers Whacked
by Nashah Adu
Mediocre is the word that
describes this golf squad at the
midway point of the season. The
team cannot seem to break the
420 stroke barrier and have a truly brilliant season; but instead,
,always finds that one score in the
90's that separates the average
team from the prime time
performer.
The Whackers lost their home
openers to Delaware and dropped
to 4-3, then placed fourth in the
Western Maryland Invitational on
Monday to round off a week of
boring and mediocre golf.
The team appears very tentative
and uncomfortable with the short
game and putting, which explains
why it is not scoring well. Coach
O'Donnell held a special 'round
the green' clinic which ought to
drive down the scores at the
Dickinson Invitational on Monday and at the MAC's next
weekend.
Blue Jays Choke Opener
The Blue Jays met Deleware at
Pine Ridge last Thursday, and
while a victory was only an outside shot, Delaware's 417 paved
the way for a rousing Hopkins
upset. Instead, the home team
fans remained disappointed. The
Whackers shot 436 which included a 96 and failed to bridge the
competitive gap between country
club and tournament golf.
Johnny Abrahams and Luigi
Handa led the dismal scoring with
86 and 85 respectively, each taking 40 putts. Luigi showed signs
of brilliance on the back nine with
an eagle on 13, but finished with
an 8 on 18 for a 38 on the
backside. Abrahams, however,
remined consistently poor
throughout his round, turning birdie opportunities into three putt
bogeys left and right.
New kid in town Marc Quardt
was the only breath of fresh air
for Hopkins. Marc combined his
sexy haircut with an equally freeflowing and suave golf swing and
went round in 82, at times making the game actually look easy.
Marc received praise from Coach
O'Donnell and seems likely to
make the trip to the MAC's.
Paul Kadri posted his first sub90 score of the season, an 87,
which is encouraging given Mr.
Kadri's heavy social schedule.
Mr. Kadri's volleyball marathon
may exclude him from several
matches just when his game
seems to be on an upswing.
The fifth score from Hopkins,
a 96 by Grizzly Walutes, was the

epitome of inconsistency and
slack golfing. Walutes probably
felt the pressure playing against
a Division One team, and his
absence from competitive play
while doing time as the team
mascot didn't help either, but it
is the mark of a true champion to
pull through against the odds, and
Walutes did not.
Western Maryland Invitational
On Monday the Whackers flew
to the Western Maryland Invitational in hopes of avenging their
lackadaisical performance against
Delaware but found themselves
mired in increasing mediocrity.
If it wasn't one thing, it was
another. While both Jon Thompson and Grizzly Walutes broke
90, Todd Stefan bloated to a 92,
and the team's total of 426 placed them fourth out of six teams.
Gettysburg emerged eventual
winners with 408, not a great
score on this pitch and putt
course. This was the same team
the Jays nipped at Gettysburg a
mere ten days ago.
Abrahams, as hehas so often
this season, lead the linksters with
an 80 but still putted 40 times.
Luigi Handa followed close
behind on 82, these low scores
being indicative of the easy
course rather than any exceptional golfing on the parts of the
Hopkins nos. 1 and 2.
Stefan's inconsistent play remains a mystery, although he
hasn't been able to practice due
to the MCATs coming up shortly. Coach O'Donnell will work
with Todd on the practice tee and
help him regain tempo and confidence, key ingredients to the
successful execution of the game.
Other Blue Jay competitors
were Steve Schiller (93) still
hungover after his first job offer,
and the lefthander Bill Rica (96).
MAC Playoff
This week's schedule is
highlighted by the intra-squad
tourney today to decide who will
represent the Whackers at the
MAC's next weekend.
This is the first time Coach
O'Donnell has introduced such a
system of qualification and it is
designed to make the players
tournament tough. Today's playoff will be shrouded with tension
as upsets can occur quite readily. No doubt the fans will be out
in numbers rooting for the local
favorite, the flamboyant Jack
Savits, whose peculiar style of hit
and run golf is particularly suited
to this situation.

from Western Maryland's speedy
attack wing.

Washington. They are also looking forward to confronting such

On Media: Small Producers are Back
by Robert Zimmerman
The movie industry is not like
it used to be. Unlike those
paradigms of power, like Sam
Goldwyn and David 0. Selznick,
today's movers and shakers are
moving around a lot and are very
shaky. Executives are losing jobs
quickly, and moving from studio
to studio even quicker. And
strategy has .changed: companies
bet on blockbuster movies to rake
in the profits and support the few
"serious" films they make.
While everyone tries to make
E. T. this leads to more
expensive—and more risky—
projects. After the failure of the
mega-expensive
Heaven's
Gate, Universal Studios had to
close.
Smaller, independent studios
are starting to emerge as new
powers in the movie industry.
Never a powerful force befcile,
the Hollywood hierarchy is get-

ting mixed up as studios never
considered "big" are starting to
infiltrate. Disney movies, written
off by Hollywooders as a cartoonfactory or a haven for Dean Jones
and Ken Berry, are back. With
Touchstone Films, Michael
Eisner has put Disney on the map
in three years.
The most startling and telling
rise is that of Cannon Pictures.
The two-man team of GolamGlobus that started, runs, and
basically is Cannon, has made the
company into the biggest independent on the movie scene.
What was only ten years ago a
third-rate independent studio that
produced dozens of low-budget
hack-and-slay horror flicks, is
now signing contracts with
Walter Matthau, Roman Polanski, and Sylvester Stallone.
In the forties, movie studios
owned a lot of their own movie
theatres, so they had places to
show the films and they got the

extra revenue. The studios today
don't do that. But Cannon did
that. Cannon Group owns over 50
movie theatres in Europe, making money for Cannon by showing Cannon films. A good
strategy.
What movie studios also don't
do today is make different kinds
of movies. As I said before,
everyone is trying to make
E.T. In the days of Sam
Goldwyn, studios had their
gangster films, their comedies,
their westerns, their musicals and
their serious films. Cannon alone
has begun to go back to that old
trend of spending less on movies
and expecting less of a return.
However, by targeting at specific
audiences, they are more assured
of the size profit they'll expect.
So, while they still churn out
blood-and-gore flicks, they also
have produced comedies (The
Private Eyes) and low-budget
serious films.

Cannon has started to attract
real stars. Roman Polanski
directed Pirates for them. The
comedy-adventure, which starred
Walter Matthau, was a flop. But
next year expect to see a Cannon
movie directed by Matthau. The
most talked about event in Cannon's history was their signing of
Sylvester Stallone to star in
Over the Top. While they did
indeed pay Sly a hefty $12 million
to play the hero in this armwrestling epic, it's not overpriced considering Marlon Brando got the same amount for his
cameo in Superman. And
whereas Brando's appearance as
Superman's father added very little to the movie (Gene Hackman
stole the whole movie anyway),
Stallone's name made this—
Cannon's first blockbuster
movie—profitable.
Sure, Over the Top wasn't
anything like Cobra or Rambo. But with foreign distribu-

tion, and video and cable rights,
Cannon made nice money on the
deal. So when you wonder who's
going to be producing the films
that'll be winning the awards at
Cannes in five years, it may be
Cannon.
The big Hollywood studios
could learn a lot from those two
middle-aged Israelis. Like that
audiences don't all want to see
another E.T.

Whackers Whacked
by Nashah Adu
Mediocre is the word that
describes this golf squad at the
midway point of the season. The
team cannot seem to break the
420 stroke barrier and have a truly brilliant season; but instead,
,always finds that one score in the
90's that separates the average
team from the prime time
performer.
The Whackers lost their home
openers to Delaware and dropped
to 4-3, then placed fourth in the
Western Maryland Invitational on
Monday to round off a week of
boring and mediocre golf.
The team appears very tentative
and uncomfortable with the short
game and putting, which explains
why it is not scoring well. Coach
O'Donnell held a special 'round
the green' clinic which ought to
drive down the scores at the
Dickinson Invitational on Monday and at the MAC's next
weekend.
Blue Jays Choke Opener
The Blue Jays met Deleware at
Pine Ridge last Thursday, and
while a victory was only an outside shot, Delaware's 417 paved
the way for a rousing Hopkins
upset. Instead, the home team
fans remained disappointed. The
Whackers shot 436 which included a 96 and failed to bridge the
competitive gap between country
club and tournament golf.
Johnny Abrahams and Luigi
Handa led the dismal scoring with
86 and 85 respectively, each taking 40 putts. Luigi showed signs
of brilliance on the back nine with
an eagle on 13, but finished with
an 8 on 18 for a 38 on the
backside. Abrahams, however,
remined consistently poor
throughout his round, turning birdie opportunities into three putt
bogeys left and right.
New kid in town Marc Quardt
was the only breath of fresh air
for Hopkins. Marc combined his
sexy haircut with an equally freeflowing and suave golf swing and
went round in 82, at times making the game actually look easy.
Marc received praise from Coach
O'Donnell and seems likely to
make the trip to the MAC's.
Paul Kadri posted his first sub90 score of the season, an 87,
which is encouraging given Mr.
Kadri's heavy social schedule.
Mr. Kadri's volleyball marathon
may exclude him from several
matches just when his game
seems to be on an upswing.
The fifth score from Hopkins,
a 96 by Grizzly Walutes, was the

epitome of inconsistency and
slack golfing. Walutes probably
felt the pressure playing against
a Division One team, and his
absence from competitive play
while doing time as the team
mascot didn't help either, but it
is the mark of a true champion to
pull through against the odds, and
Walutes did not.
Western Maryland Invitational
On Monday the Whackers flew
to the Western Maryland Invitational in hopes of avenging their
lackadaisical performance against
Delaware but found themselves
mired in increasing mediocrity.
If it wasn't one thing, it was
another. While both Jon Thompson and Grizzly Walutes broke
90, Todd Stefan bloated to a 92,
and the team's total of 426 placed them fourth out of six teams.
Gettysburg emerged eventual
winners with 408, not a great
score on this pitch and putt
course. This was the same team
the Jays nipped at Gettysburg a
mere ten days ago.
Abrahams, as hehas so often
this season, lead the linksters with
an 80 but still putted 40 times.
Luigi Handa followed close
behind on 82, these low scores
being indicative of the easy
course rather than any exceptional golfing on the parts of the
Hopkins nos. 1 and 2.
Stefan's inconsistent play remains a mystery, although he
hasn't been able to practice due
to the MCATs coming up shortly. Coach O'Donnell will work
with Todd on the practice tee and
help him regain tempo and confidence, key ingredients to the
successful execution of the game.
Other Blue Jay competitors
were Steve Schiller (93) still
hungover after his first job offer,
and the lefthander Bill Rica (96).
MAC Playoff
This week's schedule is
highlighted by the intra-squad
tourney today to decide who will
represent the Whackers at the
MAC's next weekend.
This is the first time Coach
O'Donnell has introduced such a
system of qualification and it is
designed to make the players
tournament tough. Today's playoff will be shrouded with tension
as upsets can occur quite readily. No doubt the fans will be out
in numbers rooting for the local
favorite, the flamboyant Jack
Savits, whose peculiar style of hit
and run golf is particularly suited
to this situation.
